qas.question: What method did early Chinese mathematicians use to calculate?

answers.text: a positional decimal system on counting boards

qas.question: One rod in the second box from the right is what number?
When did negative numbers and decimals start being used?

answers.text: The Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art

qas.question: What advanced mathematical methods did the Tang dynasty have?

context: Mathematics: From the earliest the Chinese used <a0_0>a positional decimal system on counting boards<a0_0/> in order to calculate. To express <a1_0>10<a1_0/>, a single rod is placed in the second box from the right. The spoken language uses a similar system to English: e.g. four thousand two hundred seven. No symbol was used for zero. By the <a2_0>1st century BC<a2_0/>, negative numbers and decimal fractions were in use and <a3_0>The Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art<a3_0/> included methods for extracting higher order roots by Horner's method and solving linear equations and by Pythagoras' theorem. <a4_0>Cubic equations<a4_0/> were solved in the Tang dynasty and solutions of equations of order higher than 3 appeared in print in 1245 AD by Ch'in Chiu-shao. Pascal's triangle for binomial coefficients was described around 1100 by Jia Xian.
